comments.commentBody:
As a young person who wanted to obliterate the Bush legacy with one transcendent vote for Obama, I can say that after two years I am now...unemployed haha!

Moral of the story: don't vote, work on election day, and hide your money from the government!
"It seems that Republicans care a lot more then Democrats..." wow, these kids are dumber then they look.
Please let this be a sign to the DNC - socially liberal fiscally responsible.  Why is this such an impossible combination for some political party to figure out?  It is not that hard people.

This particular cross-section of young voters have rather abhorrent values. I guess they're like a lot of Americans, who believe in "Death Panels" and whatever Fox news tells them to believe...loudly and with little facts behind it. If you want their vote you have to give them a job? They would have loved Tammany Hall!

Regardless of one's level of disappointment with Pres. Obama's success (or lack thereof) in making good on his promises, whether they involve economics/jobs or gay rights or this reform or that one, for somebody who supported him, who believed in the general direction of the Democratic agenda, to consider voting for a Republican is absolutely nuts to me. No, everything isn't fixed. If you really expected it to be, God bless you, but you were a little drunk on the kool-aid and hype. But if you don't know that things would be a thousand times worse if McCain had won, or that they WILL get a thousand times worse if the Republicans re-take control of Congress, then you're beyond help. They have not one even half-baked idea, other than tax-cut, tax-cut, tax-cut, and with any spending cuts coming almost totally on the back of social programs, and with zero interest in financial regulations, that will help. We will be right back to Bush's presidency and what got us into this mess to begin with, or worse, given the utterly bizarre beliefs that the various Tea-Party candidates might bring to Washington if they win.

Please don't put those yo-yo's back in charge.

Calling all young people of America!  If you want to ensure that those who brought you the Great Recession and whose articulated policies post-November will guarantee you will most assuredly not have a prayer of a chance of getting a well-paying job upon graduation (unless, of course, you are one of the lucky few who have "connections,") then, by all means, vote for any Republican candidate who comes your way this election cycle!!! But then you may not reserve the right to get mad when a Baby Boomer like myself accuses you of lacking critical thinking skills.

So fresh from living in their parent's basement our young,(who so far don't even know how to pull up their pants), are thinking about voting Republican.  Great there is no hope, our children are idiots.

'“There’s a vibe,” he said on a recent afternoon, while pumping weights at the gym. “Right now it seems like Republicans just care a lot more than Democrats.”'

Yeah - the Republicans care a lot more than the Democrats alright - they care so much they've blocked unemployment insurance extensions, small business tax credits, care for 9/11 first responders ... oh, and they really care about extending tax cuts for the wealthy.

That kid needs to get out of the gym a bit more.

If youth are becoming disenchanted now, just wait until they get a job.  I remember how frustrating it was to go from impoverished student to "rich" in the eyes of our Democrat-in-Chief. The accompanying tax burden made it difficult to save anything while paying down student loans. Buying a house, imagine my surprise to find the mortgage interest deduction phased out.  When I finally had the money to contribute to a Roth IRA, I was excluded.  The "fortunate" few will learn that being "rich" does not necessarily mean becoming wealthy anytime soon.  If youth are becoming disenchanted now, just wait they get a job!

Wow, talk about deja vu!  When I was in college and had my first chance to vote, I, too, voted for a Republican president and then again four years later.  Not long after the beginning of Reagan's second term, I began to realize the devastation my decision had brought upon the U.S.: homelessness, small towns brought to their knees by a lack of prosperity/opportunity and a health care system slowly unravelling--all thanks to deregulation and an illogical belief that cutting taxes and government services would allow everyone to live a great life (to heck with anyone who might need those services--they just needed to pull themselves up by their boot straps).  From then on, I vowed never to vote Republican again.  The resulting damage was always too severe, even when I've been frustrated with the Democrats.  I wish I knew that young voters might listen to my experiences and take heed, but alas, I recall not being interested in hearing from others at that age, either.

Murdoch is our modern day William Randolph Hearst. Hearst made up the story about the sinking of the Maine so that the USA would declare war on Spain (good for newspaper sales). Why can't Murdoch just be honest and say he supports the right wing and is fully against liberal and moderate positions.
Murdoch is dangerous. He supports Sarah Palin. If she is elected President, it would be disastrous for this country - far worse than G. Bush.

For the British police not to have cracked the crackers is incomprehnsible.
They should have set up dummy messages and stifled this plot in its crib.

This is top-class journalism and casts a much deserved light on something seriously wrong here in the UK. At the moment only the left-leaning Guardian is pursuing this story with the vigour it deserves. The BBC, like a rabbit in the headlights, is decidedly mute on this subject for fear of how the new  Murdoch-aligned government will neuter it. To me, the silence surrounding this affair is absolutely deafening. That Scotland Yard is exposed as being, at best, reluctant to confront and at worst, in actual collusion with Murdoch's news group is a genuinely terrifying development. Keep digging.

British democracy is under threat from an Australian born US citizen and now he has his man at the heart of the British government.
Any story that exposes his empire for what it really is lessens that threat.
Thank you NYT.

What may seem a minor quibble on the other side of the Atlantic - but the bbc is not a government-financed organisation.  It receives it's income directly from the public in the form of an annual licence. It's not paid for in other words out of taxation - government-funding - despite the widespread fallacy around the world that it is. But, sure: it is a PUBLICLY-funded broadcaster, which protects it from the commercial pressures of owners like Murdoch.

I had to laugh at comment # 23 "their entire spoiled,privliged lives are supported by British taxpayers." Who do you think the super-rich American royal families are supported by? And we have thousands of times more of idle, thieving rich than do the British- they only have the Royal Family.

Since this is happening in Britain to royals, it could be happening anywhere to anyone. While people wouldn't want to listen to what normal people talk about, the issue of our privacy being invaded is alarming.
Maybe I'm jumping to conclusions, but doesn't this mean other people, with the right tools, can hack into our calls too?

Maybe the Royals Privacy is over-rated...

This 'gotta have it now' world we live in has too many secrets...
Scotland Yard... What a gass !!! Chasing their tails for the Royals...

This article only discusses swing speed as the main factor in determining the right ball. What it fails to address is that the right golf ball for your game is a combination of fitting for your ball speed, launch angle and spin as well as your on-course preferences off the tee, in the fairway and on the green. This approach, used by GolfBallSelector.com, provides for a more comprehensive ball fitting.

A hole in my Beatles and SImpson's knowledge prevented me from finishing the bottom left, but I managed to get the rest and am proud of it. Thanks, John, for a good one.

Was I the only one who started out with PASTIES in 14D? It kept me from getting that corner for a long time.

Hey, I hope you guys had fun trashing the food at the Open.  Wondering how many dishes you tried.  I had the terrific mozzarella salad and prosciutto bread at the wine bar.  At the Master Chef Catina, two of my friends got the bbq pulled pork sandwich with mango slaw and another friend picked up a shrimp dog.  Both  awesome!   I know it's fun to "skewer" and "roast",  but recommendations would be a lot more useful to your readers.

It was a tough match to watch...but after the other notable upsets so far it's hard to not root for the American underdog at least for awhile.

@jsf: the score is under the photo: 6-2, 6-2, 6-4
Boo-hoo! Is it not possible for American tennis stars to lose with some grace? (ie Serena last year).
@JSF The score is under the picture as a caption right at the top, and anyway, not the point -- loved this piece, a pleasant break from the usual sports reporting.

Some people have it, some people do not! Upsets are only interesing if they mark the decline of the player upset. If they simply are deviations, then they demonstrate that a less talented player can win once in a while. But who cares?

Rooting for an upset is like hoping to hear Placido Domingo sing a bad note. The upset player is only human. The lesser player remains lesser. Max Schmelling beat Louis only to have the laws of nature return to their usual functional state and get demolished by Louis at the rematch.

Andy Roddick will only win if the good players have the flu! Unless he just likes being on the tour (which is not a bad way to make a living), then he should quit! Losing is for losers!
